image.altText: Police in Queensland use wanding to search for knives

props.synopsis: The legislation, known as Jack's Law, allows police to use handheld metal detectors to search people without a warrant.

title.children: Extraordinary stop and search powers expanded to Queensland shopping centres

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black jacket arrives at court

props.synopsis: The Brittany Higgins and Linda Reynolds defamation trial hears revelations lawyers have launched another lawsuit against Ms Higgins which attempts to make access to her federal government settlement easier.

title.children: Fresh lawsuit against Brittany Higgins launched by Linda Reynolds amid defamation dispute

image.altText: A montage of photos of Angus Beaumont, who was killed in 2020.

props.synopsis: One of the teenagers who killed 15-year-old Angus Beaumont has been charged with attempted murder just seven months since his release from detention and while on bail.

title.children: Teen who killed Angus Beaumont charged with attempted murder just seven months after release

image.altText: An excavator sinking into mud at a mine.  A large dozer is being used to drag it out.

props.synopsis: Byerwen coal mine workers are reeling from the death of a second worker at the same Bowen Basin mine this month.

title.children: Coal miner dies in second fatal incident at Bowen Basin mine this month

image.altText: A wide shot of the booking.com website on a laptop with a person sitting in front.

props.synopsis: Online platforms have made it easier and cheaper to organise accommodation, but their rise in popularity has also led to a spike in scams.Â Here's how to check if your booking is legitimate, and how to avoid being scammed in the first place.

title.children: How to know if your accommodation booking is a scam

image.altText: a man holding metal detecting equipment on the left and a circular tag on the right

props.synopsis: The Brisbane detectorist has reunited a US family with their relatives dog tags. Now he's appealing to Sydney to locate an Australian ex-servicemen's descendants.

title.children: Metal detectorist on mission to return WWII dog tags to soldier's family

image.altText: A middle-aged bald man in a suit smiles as he walks down a corridor with an ABC News logo behind him.

props.synopsis: Mr Anderson says he will remain in the role at the request of ABC chair Kim Williams until a new managing director is appointed, likely early next year.

title.children: ABC managing director David Anderson announces intention to resign from national broadcaster

image.altText: A smiling older woman sitting in a bar with a beer.

props.synopsis: Premier Steven Miles has pledged to erect a statue in honour of the late activist and author, who was instrumental in bringing about reforms to allow women to drink in pubs and to continue working in the public service after marriage.

title.children: Queensland government reveals plan to immortalise feminist icon Merle Thornton

image.altText: A man bows before a crowd

props.synopsis: With Oprah sneaking in for a surprise address and Bill Clinton returning to the spotlight, Tim Walz enjoyed a star-studded opening act before he made his debut. This is what you missed on day three of the Democratic convention.

title.children: Oprah's 'childless cat ladies' and Bill Clinton's age barbs: Democrats bring the Trump zingers on DNC day three

image.altText: A young child gets there nose blown.

props.synopsis: Infectious disease experts say pregnant women should get vaccinated urgently as whooping cough numbers reach a nine-year high.Â

title.children: 'Shocking' whooping cough numbers are being reported across Australia. Here's why

image.altText: Bemir Saracevic

props.synopsis: The federal government has ordered an investigation after the ABC uncovered allegations of bikie threats towards the CFMEU on a major taxpayer-funded project in Brisbane.

title.children: Federal government orders investigation into alleged bikie threats towards CFMEU

image.altText: Anthony Albanese during QT

props.synopsis: It's been no secret that Australia's parliament has cultural problems; stories of bullying and intimidation in the house on the hill are the thing of legends. But there are signs of change.

title.children: Parliament was built for conflict. Now there are signs of change

image.altText: Monash IVF sign

props.synopsis: More than 700 patients filed a class action against the fertility company, claiming potentially viable embryos were wrongfully discarded and misused.

title.children: Monash IVF agrees to $56m settlement over alleged improper use of patient embryos

image.altText: Green fields and some small buildings are seen with plumes of smoke rising and small yellow explosions from above

props.synopsis: Ukrainian intelligence could be targeting Russian forces using social media or geolocation data, the interior ministry said via Telegram.

title.children: Avoid dating apps and social media, Russian government warns Kursk residents

image.altText: A regional express airplane

props.synopsis: Hundreds of former Rex employees could face an even longer wait to be paid their entitlements after administrators applied for an extension to find a buyer for the airline.

title.children: Rex administrators request more time to secure 'highest possible value' for collapsed airline

image.altText: An inflatable slide attached to the side of a Jetstar aeroplane.

props.synopsis: The flight from Sydney had just parked at Melbourne Airport when a man opened an emergency exit door, in a situation a passenger described as "really strange".

title.children: Jetstar passenger describes how man 'ripped off' plane's emergency exit door at Melbourne Airport

image.altText: Indigenous woman looks out the window from the rundown kitchen.

props.synopsis: A class action has been filed against the West Australian government on behalf of thousands of tenants living in substandard public housing in remote Aboriginal communities.Â

title.children: These Australians have been 'ignored and forgotten' in the housing crisis

image.altText: Ruthy Hewson getting hair cut

props.synopsis: Growing up, Ruthy Hewson felt salons didn't know how to care for her textured hair. Today, hairdressers are working to change the stigma that afro-textured hair can be difficult to style.

title.children: 'We can be beautiful with our natural hair': Stylists working to improve salon experience for all hair types

image.altText: Two graves dug in dusty ground are adorned with flowers at a funeral in Nir Oz.

props.synopsis: Avraham Munder was among the 70 people taken hostage during the October 7 attack on his kibbutz, and he has now finally been laid to rest alongside his son by grieving and angry family and loved ones.

title.children: He spent 10 months in captivity in Gaza and died in mysterious circumstances. Now Avraham has been laid to rest

image.altText: Surfers and swimmers in the water at Bondi Beach in calm conditions.

props.synopsis: Above-average temperatures are forecast all across Australia as we reach the tail end of winter. But is the cold weather truly behind us?

title.children: Summer heat arrives in August, threatening to break all-time Australian winter temperature records

image.altText: Jayson Gillham sits on a step outside in a professional portrait photo

props.synopsis: Jayson Gillham, whose scheduled performance with the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra was abruptly cancelled last week, talks about choosing to highlight the plight of journalists in Gaza at concert.

title.children: Pianist had 'no idea' his Gaza comments would spark a firestorm with the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra

image.altText: Aftermath of missile attack in Russia's Kursk

props.synopsis: Russia's Ministry of Defence says it shot down a swathe of Ukrainian drones in one of Kyiv's "largest attempts" to attack Moscow using drones.

title.children: Kyiv's Russian counteroffensive continues with 'largest' attempted drone attack

image.altText: A graphic reading death certificate

props.synopsis: Medical staff at Tasmania's second-largest hospital say what the public know is just "the tip of the iceberg" when it comes to unexpected deaths going unreported to the coroner.

title.children: 'I can't put you through': Doctor claims he wasn't allowed to contact coroner after patient's death

image.altText: O'Neill is sitting in the Senate chamber with a finger raised and calling out to the government benches.

props.synopsis: Taiwan's de facto embassy in Canberra praises Australia after the Senate passed a bipartisan motion criticising China's attempts to use a 50-year-old UN resolution to claim Taiwan as part of its territory.

title.children: Australia backs Taiwan in Senate motion likely to infuriate China

image.altText: Donald Trump stands behind bullletproof glass onstage at an outdoor rally.

props.synopsis: At his first outdoor rally since last month's attempted assassination, Donald Trump spoke from behind bulletproof glass, but he also casually wandered out to greet crowds.Â

title.children: Trump speaks behind bulletproof glass at first outdoor rally since attempted assassination

image.altText: Mike Lynch smiles as he wears a suit and walks from the High Court.

props.synopsis: The Italian coastguard say the body of Mike Lynch has been recovered from the wreckage of a superyacht.

title.children: Body of British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch recovered from superyacht wreckage

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and his government stand up in parliament with their hands clasped, looking solemn.

props.synopsis: Beyond the heat in the chamber, the two sides of politics have been quietly working together behind the scenes on important reforms.

title.children: Beyond the arguments and name-calling, the two sides of politics have been quietly working together

image.altText: Bill Shorten during QT

props.synopsis: The federal government has cleared its political hurdle with states and territories to reform the NDIS, but it now faces a very apprehensive disability community.

title.children: What happens now the government has support for its contentious NDIS reforms?

image.altText: A portrait photo of Elon Musk. He is a white man with short black hair and brown eyes, wearing a black suit.

props.synopsis: Data provided exclusively to the ABC shows Tesla's "brand health" in Australia has plummeted as some EV buyers say, "Musk has convinced me I don't want to buy a Tesla".

title.children: Does Tesla have a Musk problem? Data shows its reputation in Australia is tanking as sales fall

image.altText: Pink roses.

props.synopsis: A bouquet of flowers is the go-to gift for many special occasions but the world is paying a high price for transporting our out-of-season blooms.

title.children: Do you really know where the flowers you buy come from? You might be shocked

image.altText: Pile of frozen pea packets

props.synopsis: Supermarkets are seemingly offering more brands of frozen veggies than ever â but is the increasing choice an illusion?

title.children: The rise of 'phantom brands' as supermarket giants sneak imports onto shelves, pushing Australian produce out

image.altText: Comanchero Outlaw Motorcycle Gang clothing, methamphetamine, phones, cash and other items laid out on the ground.

props.synopsis: Police in Tonga say an alleged Comancheros gang member deported from Australia was behind moves to establish the outlaw motorcycle group in the Pacific island â an attempt they say was disrupted in a drug bust this month.

title.children: Tonga police swoop on alleged Comanchero gang member once deported from Australia

image.altText: Whale leaps from water.

props.synopsis: Tour operators say they're experiencing one of the busiest spotting seasons in years off the coast of Townsville, where the "calves are playful" and breaching and flipper slaps are plentiful.

title.children: Bumper whale watching season along North Queensland's 'humpback highway'
